string.name: about_info
string.Data:
Contact

If you have questions, concerns, comments or feedback, please feel free to contact us at surfacewaterquality@andaker.com.

Privacy Policy

string.name: app_info
string.Data:
Application Information

General

The Surface Water Quality application provides testing results for water monitored by state, federal, tribal and local agencies. The data is collected from the Water Quality Portal (WQP) which is a service sponsored by the United States Geological Survey (USGS), the Environmental Protection Services (EPA), and the National Water Quality Monitoring Council (NWQMC).

Warning: This application is designed only to present existing data provided through the WQP and is not intended to by a primary source for evaluating if a body of water is safe to use for fishing, swimming or other recreational purposes. It is also important to note that water quality can vary significantly over time and in response to various events (e.g. storms, drought, temperature, etc.).

Technical

This application gathers data from the WQP, over the last 16 months, and compares the results against the National Recommended Water Quality Criteria, which are developed by the EPA under Section 304(a) of the Clean Water Act. These recommended criteria represent specific levels of chemicals or conditions in a water body that are expected to not cause adverse effects to human health. EPA provides recommendations for consumption of “water + organism” and “organism only” human health criteria; however, with this application, we only consider the less stringent "organism only" criteria to provide a reference for individuals who wish to use a body of water for recreational purposes (e.g. fishing and swimming). You can find a table of these recommended criteria here.

All criteria should be considered when evaluating a body of water for fishing; however, only pathogens (e.g. Escherichia coli, Enterococci and historically fecal coliforms) and cyanotoxins (draft recommendations) are currently used by the EPA to evaluate whether a body of water is safe for swimming. You can find more details about the pathogen thresholds and our conservative assumptions to simplify the results in the limit info section when a result is selected.

Using the Application

Find a Monitoring Station

When the application launches you will see a map. Slide the map around to find monitoring locations. A message will display with instructions to zoom in or out if there are no stations or too many stations to display. If needed, click on a marker cluster icon to zoom into individual stations. Stations are only displayed if results are available within the last 16 months and are color coded by warning level. Each result is assigned a warning level based on the criteria recommended limits, if available, and each station is assigned a warning level based on the most recent results for each chemical or condition. Result warning level are assigned as follows:

resources.string: Concentration is 90% or greater of the recommended level
Concentration is between 60% and 90% of the recommended level
Concentration is less than 60% of the recommended level

string.name: view_limits_and_historical_results
string.Data:
Viewing Results

To view location details and results for a particular monitoring station, click on the station marker. Station details are displayed followed by a list of the most recent results for each chemical or condition. Results are ordered first by highest warning level, if one exists, and then by date.

Viewing Recommended Criteria Limits and Historical Results

To view the recommended limits and any historical results for a chemical or condition, click on the desired result. This will display a screen with the limit information followed by a graph with all the historical results, including the most recent result, available over the past 16 months. If a limit is available for the chemical or condition, a red line is drawn on the graph to indicate the limit level. Any result measurements reported as not detected, present below quantification limit, or trace are included in the historical graph as zero.
